awd_titl_txt: Increasing Science, Mathematics, and Computer Science Opportunities for Low-Income Undergraduate Students

por.por_cntn:
The S-STEM Scholarship Program at New Jersey City University (NJCU) endeavored to develop an effective model for student success at institutions that serve economically disadvantaged urban students, in particular underrepresented minorities. Key components of the program were faculty mentoring and monitoring, academic support in the form of supplemental instruction and tutoring, and community building by means of study groups and program meetings.

During the five years of the program, a total of 76 students majoring in biology, chemistry, computer science, geoscience, mathematics, or physics were awarded scholarships. Of these students 66 (87%) were retained in NJCU STEM degree programs or graduated from NJCU with STEM degrees. Of the retained or graduated scholarship recipients, 59% were female, 41% were Hispanic, and 11% were Black; 3% of the students identified themselves as both Black and White. The program retention rate of 87% was far higher than the overall retention rate in STEM disciplines at NJCU. Scholarship recipients excelled in the classroom: over the course of the project, 80-90% of scholarship recipient grades in STEM courses were B- or above, compared to 50-60% in non scholarship cohorts.

The project helped to vitalize and strengthen STEM education at NJCU. During the five years of the program, the F/W rate in gatekeeper courses fell by 8%, and the number of STEM graduates increased by 48%. Scholarship recipients were important consumers of academic support services and undergraduate research opportunities, lending impetus to several University initiatives in the area of STEM education: creation of the HUB (a University-wide consolidated tutoring service for mathematics and English), the Office of Supplemental Instruction, and the NJCU Scientific Undergraduate Research Institute (SURI).


Last Modified: 07/31/2017
Modified by: Sandra M Caravella
